Despite the new Pavillion and the never ending tech integration, the hospital is overwhelmingly understaffed

job_title: Patient Service Associate in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros:
Growth opportunities within Penn, especially if you take advantage of tuition benefits - however you will likely need to leave your department, specialty, division, hospital, etc to get there
Strong personal connections - if you have a great manager who fosters a positive environment and hires the right people
cons:
Same title positions paid about the same across medical specialties, even if your specialty/patient populations requires more scheduling work (ie long term diseases/treatments vs elective cosmetic procedures)
Raises are not based on years served or any merits/metrics - coworkers who do less will get the same reward you do
You will need to leave your department to find growth opportunities
It's a healthcare job, you'll be expected to do a lot because it's the "right" thing and the patients needs come first - this can be incredibly rewarding when you help someone who is appreciative, but can also be frustrating when they're not

review_title: Great organization, limited opportunities for advancement
pros:
Benefits
Coworkers who really care, and who you can learn from
Mission of the organization
Learning from doctors
cons:
Raises - no merit based increases. Cost of living is updated for all employees the same way. Hard work doesn't get recognized by pay increase compared to the organization as a whole
Hard workers get "rewarded" with more work, but not more $ or title change
Very political - certain departments will promote their team while others will give a year+ run around on what "might be possible" and never happens. 
Good people usually leave before getting a promotion, because it will likely never come. 
"Yes people" get promoted, even if they aren't the most strategic or with the strongest productivity, but their boss likes them. Good talent leaves because they are not valued, while mediocre staff are retained and even promoted if they play the game. Leadership is out of touch and has no idea what goes on in the day to day.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work
pros: Opportunity for growth. I see a lot of people saying that growth isn’t possible at penn, but i don’t believe that’s true. Maybe not in your specific department, but I’ve seen a lot of people move from the call center to much higher positions. If you work hard, and apply to the next level in another department, you are likely to get it. Another pro, Penn does not look at you for education only. You could have a masters and no experience and someone with a bachelors and 5 years experience is more likely to get a job. And finally, while this may not be true for all departments, i feel everyone is treated with respect and equality. You don’t hear providers demanding their team call them “Dr” and they treat you as their equal. I’ve worked many places where this is not the case!!!
cons: Pay can be low- but to be fair, it’s super mixed. Some positions are paid way above the National average and some seem exceptionally low. Currently understaffed and many people are working many hours of overtime with no extra compensation. I feel strongly that salaried or not, you should be compensated for your hard work! I don’t like the underlying message of “no one is making you” - yes no one is making us, but you know we’re going to because most of us take these jobs to move up and earn a good reputation! Further more, you know who you’re hiring! You know we aren’t going to just let everything fall apart.

pros: Excellent teamwork in the departments I worked.  My nurse managers always gave me flexible schedules to help me get through school and taught me a lot. I had most of my most exceptional work experiences at Penn. I received three degrees working at The Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania.  I  gained a lot of knowledge far beyond my job description from the doctors, nurses, and other staff. They were always willing to teach.
cons: The Human Resources Department does not take the time for retention of good employees, especially the employees that have received degrees.  Some employees get hired or moved into positions with no experience at all by default of the jobs they are in or because they know the right people in the top areas.  One of my biggest disappointments was watching so many excellent employees with years of experience consistently overlooked.  Managers let employees advance and stop trying to hold them in the department because they do not want to look for new employees. Put more effort in making your employees happy. Make work-life balance better. Make parking cheap or free like the other hospitals for employees. Every employee should be able to get a vacation every year.

review_title: Marketing = a MIXED BAG; Print team not recommended
pros:
-good name to add to your resume
-a stepping stone
-there are only about two handfuls of great people that work here from both, the web/digital and marketing suites/teams. These people are friendly, approachable, willing to teach/learn, care about their work, want others to succeed and are passionate about what they do. Only they make this place worth it.
cons:
-Some marketing managers are great while others are awful. You have to get lucky to land a spot on a great print marketing team.
-ZERO to barely any growth potential. Example: some employees on the web/digital marketing team have been there for over 8+ years without a single promotion. Some managers like to dangle the carrot of promises of a promotion for yearssssss.
-The marketing print team is separated from the web digital marketing team; organizationally as well as physically. Makes no sense. So if you are looking to getting hands-on experience on everything marking (print, seo, website, blogs, ads, etc) this not going to happen here. Both teams should be integrated. If you land a job on the print marketing side, you may end up just doing only outdated print tactics, which will not help you grow in today's marketing world.
-Low pay
-Print marketing suite = only management has windows. If you are looking for vitamin D here you are out of luck
-Cube Farm
-Very outdated office space
-Moderate turnover
-People get pushed out to leave (in about 1 yr I witnessed approx. 3)

job_title: Clinical Nurse Practitioner in Philadelphia, PA
pros: You work with talented clinical staff in a culture that emphasizes evidence-based medicine and you get to care for a diverse group of patients and patient problems.
cons: Management and Corporate does not respect its staff and treats them like they are replaceable widgets. At times it seems like they do more to try and stifle innovation than to promote it. job_title: Senior Staff Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
1. Stability
2.  Most staff are very nice as are most physicians
cons:
1.  There is no accountability of mid to upper management-they can do no wrong

2. Human Resources will not investigate mid to upper management and complaints on managerial behavior (or any other complaints) will go ignored and in some cases, covered up.

3.  Expect to be written up for being 1 minute late-in defiance of HUPs own punch-in policies and state law.

4.  Expect to work through lunch breaks or be written up for not completing tasks.

5.  Management does not value staff.  Their attitude is "you are lucky to work here, if you don't like it, leave".

6.  If you cross management, they will find a way to either a. make your work days miserable enough to want to resign, or b. force you out through inventing rule violations and utilize "progressive step" write ups to dismiss you.  Complaints are futile. HR is a joke.

7.  Although this employer advertises their "generous sick days and time off", they are severely restricted in practice.

8.  If you call in sick the day before or after a Holiday, this employer will not pay you for your Holiday.

9.  Management does not communicate HUP policies and department polices to employees.

job_title: New Patient Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Tuition reimbursement is unmatched in the region; many opportunities to work closely with some of the best doctors in the country.
cons: They offer absolutely no performance-based raises whatsoever. They make a huge deal when they give you the 3% cost of living raise (which is not every year). They have a "we don't need to pay you well because you get to tell people you work at Penn" attitude. I've been working there for 3 years and still can't even afford my own apartment. If you work at Penn know you benefit from being lazy more than from working hard.

pros: One of the most competitive companies to work for. Health insurance and employee benefits are the best in Philadelphia and the tri-state area.
cons:
Policies are not the same, it varies depending on which hospital you work in. Most departments have a high turn over rate due to management and scheduling issues, a problem that varies depending on the location in which you work in. 

They promote career advancement via a nice size tuition reimbursement package, but once you have completed your education its hard to find a position that allows for you to utilize the degree. If your education isn't in nursing then you are hard pressed to move up the career ladder. As a result one might look for employment elsewhere.

review_title: Amazing in some ways, crappy in others
job_title: Clinical Services Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great health insurance, lots of career opportunities
cons: Well below average pay, they take PTO for literally everything, without allowing any flexibility in your schedule at all

review_title: Clinical Nurse Research Coordinator at FTD Center
pros: If you are really into generating new research, the docs are great mentors.  If you are Caucasian, you will really fit into the culture here.
cons: Little accessibility, no transparency. Clinical care is put on the back burner.  These providers only check their phones/EPIC once a week, sometimes only once every 2 weeks.  They expect you to manage medications and call in/sign orders such as meds and PT/OT/ST even though that is not the RN's scope of practice.  They will tell you with empty words that they care about you and want to make sure you feel comfortable in your job.

pros: Chestnut Hill Hospital is located on a beautiful campus in Philadelphia.  It is easy to get to because it is located near public transportation.  Most of the people are friendly.
cons: Employees are treated like children.  Management questions every decision- no matter how small.  Employees are given "incidents" when taking sick days- even with a doctor's note.  Too many incidents and you are written up/disciplined.  Sick days are provided, but not meant to be used.  There is zero work life balance.  Vacation days are accrued, which is fine, but then you are forced to take them when you don't want to- before all holidays and sometimes at random.  Benefits are expensive and not very good.  There is a deductible on the prescriptions!

review_title: Penn Home Care and Hospice Services:  Dysfunctional, and they know it.
pros: Penn doesn't fire anyone, they just transfer people to a different department.
cons:
This is the department they transfer people to when they don't want to deal with them - including management/leadership.  

The field staff are frequently frustrated because of managerial issues, but the managers are only allowed _minimal_ operating room by senior "leadership", who want _total_ control.  The result is an organization that performs with little to no efficiency and no cohesion. There is a culture of blame that abounds and they are well aware of it.  Any opposing voice is quickly demoted, transferred, or encouraged to quit through passive aggressive means.

pros: The health benefits are great.
cons: Employees were treated like a number. Human resources was virtually nonexistent in my department for the benefit of the employee, leaving management to get away with unfair practices. Nothing was transparent or honest. We took an employee survey and were not allowed to see the results and were told like children, we wouldn't understand them. Rampant sexism, nepotism and favoritism. Furthering your career path was shunned upon as no one in management or leadership would be willing to give you a recommendation in fear of retribution. Training was not encouraged. I was given more and more work out of my job description, I asked for a title change only and I was denied. I soon left and found out they hired someone with the title I had created myself and asked for. Employees were literally yelled and cursed at by management in an office where everyone else could hear what was happening. There were mass exoduses of employees who got fed up.

review_title: Greatst hands to be in as a patient receiving care....
pros:
Tolerant, patient, prductive and objective team!!!!  Will, Paul and the whole gang all are at an excellent pace and place in their careers practicing focused compassion.  In 2017 this is rare.  I needed their help and time and they gave it with a standard setting attitude.  Their lovingness and approachability sealed the deal for me and encouraged continued healing and rehabilitation.  Thank you Penn Medicine.  I am remorseful for unfair judgments I have made against you and the hospital in the past.

What beauty and reliability tere is here.

I salute you and thank you for your life!
PAT
cons: The only thing I can fairly say is that you seem to be a bit of extra confusion with shift changes especially during the weekend and skeleton crew coordination.

pros: Penn has excellent benefits and good pay.  Its easy to transfer out of a department and move on to another area.  The location is great and accessible to several forms of public transportation
cons: depending on the dept sometimes there are unfair practices such as some people not pulling their weight, parking isnt great.  You have to either come very early and park a few blocks away and walk or park in a lot where you could pay upwards of $20 per day.  Also the politics here are really crazy at times

review_title: Great Environment, but very a very large company
pros: Supportive environment, always new technology & processes to learn. Interesting business processes to learn as well. Managers & Co-Workers are supportive and helpful when learning new things. Benefits are very good as well.
cons: A very large company with many different computer systems and departments that do not communicate with each other.  Tuition benefits are good but having to wait 3 years to use the dependent tuition benefit and having it only available for dependents at UPenn makes it more of a perk than a benefit. I mean the university side of Penn supports dependents at any accredited school why can't the Medical side do the same. Salary increases are small and the same across the board for everyone.

pros: It is a dynamic multidisciplinary workplace that is stimulating and fast-paced.  There are many outstanding practitioners who deliver state-of-the-art cancer care to a broad cross section of the surrounding area.  There are many resources within the health system for supporting patients and family members through their treatment including nutrition, social work, meditation, rehabilitation etc..
cons: It is a morass which is poorly managed and very user-unfriendly.  Accessing the system requires perseverence and persistence which may be difficult when one is ill.  Management is more focused on the big picture than the patient experience and assumes that people will come for care because of the big name physicians.  There is little attention to human resources and opportunities for advancement (if you are not a physician) are few and far between.

review_title: A good experience overall, divided leadership in my division made things challenging at times
job_title: R&D Staff for Hospital Department in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
-Smart, dedicated people
-Each department/division has high impact/innovative projects - it is important for individuals to actively seek these projects if they want to advance their career
-Intense but in a way that fosters dedication
cons:
-Politics - tensions run high in certain divisions, higher than I have seen at many other places
-Like all academic institutions, processes often run slow
-Very difficult to climb to a high position without very impressive educational credentials - this is both a strength and a weakness (pedigree can be over-emphasized)

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Accessible to public transportation.  LUCY bus is free with PENN ID to and from train station.
cons: Salaries vary for same job. A patient service rep in one department could earn several dollars more per hour in a hospital based department compared to a clinical practice department - same job, same experience, very different pay.  Access to salary information is not accessible or posted.  A new hire could earn a higher salary for same job, same experience, different department.  Didn't the President of the US recently sign a law allowing access to this information?

review_title: A great to place to work
pros: The benefits are good. The atmosphere is wonderful. The hospital and school have a great repretation and would love for my children to attend the school.  It is a peaceful place to work and if hired longterm great things can come from working here.  Its great that they pay for school and want to see  you get further in life.
cons: The dental plan sucks and you can't express your feelings about alot of things to management.  Senior management needs to come and see what goes on and what does not go on in the offices even its once a year.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The University of Penn was a great place to work if you are looking for good health and tuition benefits. Location is good in respect to public transportation.
cons: The politics that go on among physicians\nurses and clinical management is somewhat uncivilized. Nurses and physician bicker in front of patients and their families, which I found very offensive. Some clinical staff members are very arrogant and unpleasant at times.

review_title: Great people to work with. No advancement!
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Phila, PA
pros: It's such a friendly environment to work in. Tuition reimbursement is awesome if you plan on staying with the company.
cons: No room for advancement. If you are friends with management then they will make sure that you are on the correct career path. I served almost 3 years at Penn and they sued me for my tuition I am still paying them back! It is hard to get an interview it takes a couple months.

review_title: Working at Penn Medicine was the best professional experience I've had to date.
job_title: Patient Services Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The people I had the privilege of working for at Penn Medicine were first class. The professional work environment was met by friendly management and strong leaders who were willing to coach me to succeed at my job. There were also many opportunities for advancement within the company.
cons: The main con of working for any company so large are that it can be difficult to navigate professional channels. There are, however, many paths available if looking to move around the organization.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great exposure to hospital environment if you’re a student of nursing or pharmacy. Benefits are good.
cons: Rarely ever get trained on anything but med deliveries, cliques all around from “vet” techs, also known as techs who have been around a long time. If someone who has been there for a while decides they don’t like you and tells management that you’re not a good employee, they don’t question it. They only do peer evaluations not manager or pharmacist evaluations so don’t make any enemies.

pros:
Pros: great bosses, team-like atmosphere at work, looks great on a resume, they were very flexible about giving me time of or adjusting my hours to better suit me.

Please note, I worked in one small division.  Your findings may be vastly different.
cons: Cons: parking is ridiculously expensive.  Within the work groups, there tends to be a fair amount of drama, particularly among MAs and PSRs.  Stay away from that.  Other simple hassles, like a new training program meant I couldn't get into Epic (our EMR system) for days until the next training session.  It does happen everywhere though.

review_title: Great Unit in a Great Hospital
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The hospital of the University of Pennsylvania truly values nurses, as evidenced by a nurse being hired as CEO of the hospital, whom was our Chief Nursing Executive prior to being promoted. Educational opportunities, work with amazing colleagues, and it is part of an Ivy League institution with the best nursing school in the country.
cons: Nothing specifically about this institution, but rather nursing in general so use your imagination. However, I will say that through the shared governance structure and nursing administration and clinical nurse specialists opportunities to turn cons into pros is possible

review_title: Over ten years and still love this place!
pros: Coworkers, benefits, EDUCATION 100% paid up front 8000/yr nothing out of pocket, access and exposure to world class leaders in the field. A chance to be involved in the forefront of medicine.
cons: The work can be hard and the pressure high but that is part of being involved in medicine and academia. Always room to improve but you don't see me looking to leave.

review_title: Offers excellent benefits. Mostly supported by middle management.  Needs improvement with fairness of hiring practices.
pros: Health and tuition benefits are very good. Small community feeling among staff through out the institution. Immediate managers are more approachable. Many support services are understaffed and their concerns sometimes go unrecognized.
cons: Upper management is aloof unapproachable. I find that it's who you know more than what you know with hiring practices. Human Resources supports management and there are some concerns as to fairness when being outspoken.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Radnor, PA
pros: excellent benefits such as health, 401k, paid tuition etc.
cons: Poorly managed. Every day guide lines change on how practices are to be run, doctor's think they are Gods and make up their own rules and don't listen to management. If you are dealing with an irate patient, don't expect the manager to step in and help, you're on your own. PSR's are overworked and get no recognition, patients are rude all day every day and no one checks to make sure that you, the employee, are ok. Have a complaint about the head of your department? You will get nowhere with complaints, and they get away with everything, even stealing.

pros: With many several grea academic institutions in the Philadelphia area Penn is second to none. It is truly a leader in medicine in too many areas to list here. It has launched and made the careers of so many including nursing as well.  If you want an amazing experience-and in a compressed amount of time-Penn is the place.
cons: Not many, corporate feel, inefficient support service in certain areas come to mind over years. But it serves so many in such complex ways can become quite a challenge. Pros way outweigh cons.

pros: Very good benefits, SOME nice coworkers in department. Nice nurses and residents and other staff. Tuition assistance would’ve been nice to use.
cons: My department had some extremely rude coworkers. Co workers should not be allowed to treat each other this way! Extremely high workloads to the point of being unsafe and then told I had poor time management. Was told this in the beginning even when I was still on orientation and learning. Was criticized from day one and never given a chance to adjust to new hospital. I was at my previous employer for 10 years and have never had this problem before in my career!

review_title: Time there has been very fulfilling helping patients during difficult times.
job_title: Patient Registration Worker in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great tuition, medical and dental benefits.  Pay rate much higher than other nearby hospitals.  Looks very good on your resume.
cons: Hard to transfer once your there. Also, company is very concerned about appearances, will spend copious amounts of money to make it "pretty" but not on staff to accommodate patient volume.

pros: It was a bad economy and I was switching fields so I was lucky to find a job.  I was able to work hands-on on desktops, laptops and printers.  I liked my coworkers.
cons: I did not believe that there was any oppurtunity for me to move into a technician or helpdesk role, so matter how much time I worked that this role.  The hiring for certain roles seemed to be gender-biased.  Compensation did not cover basic cost-of-living in this area of the country.  I could not afford to take sick days (no PTO) so I came to the hospital sick or not.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Phila, PA
pros: Pay is relatively decent/ fair for one's designated job title. Overall professional atmosphere. Like many jobs in the medical field, it is primarily women as far as medical assistants and front desk reception, so there is some degree of cattiness to be expected. Most of the employees know where to draw the line and make sure their respective jobs aren't in jeopardy. You work for the company, not the doctors, so like some past employers I've had, if a physician does not like you, it is not their call whether you remain with the company. There is a protocall that is followed regarding discipline. There is favoritism at any job but overall, it is a professional company with a formality implemented and office managers are held responsible to treat everyone fairly. There is a $1,000 bonus once a year and a  3% non-performance based raise every year. Benefits are good including tuition assistance (not reimbursement, but actual upfront payment to your school). Promotion within is preferred. Also never a dull moment with a variety of patient personalities and there is always something to be learned.
cons: The non performance based raise prevents over achievers from being compensated for their hard work, so an employee who puts half effort into their work, will get the same raise as someone who works twice as hard. You wont get a significant raise unless you completely make a change in job title and are moved or promoted to a different department that pays more. There can be a lot of pressure to uphold company's standards and patients are very demanding due to the reputation of the company, their expectations can be high and they can have a tendency to forget that they are not the only patient we are treating and some tasks require patience. Management is expected to maintain the same reputation as the regular employees so sometimes there is a trickle-down effect where their pressure is put on to us. Most physicians have a high volume of patients and have high expectations of their Medical assistants. Patients often assume you are a nurse and expect medical advice.

review_title: Great environment to learn as well as be challenged with some of the most tasking problems of our time in the field.
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Very cooperative team
Great Benefits 
Innovative projects 
Very nice coworkers 
They make provisions for all the things that allow you to become efficient especially if you're willing to really work hard and smart. 
Really enhances your team working abilities and your networking behaviors.
cons: Pay is little low but compared to similar institutions they are right up there especially if you're starting out at entry level. You could find private companies that would offer more of course. Of course the normal bureaucratic headache of a large institution

job_title: Nurse Clinical Documentation Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Networking among various multi-discipline professionals.
cons: Recent corporate consolation which resulted in micromanagement of reviewers to the point where the objective CDI focus was disconnected.  Fortunately, there was a restructure of the leadership and maybe the new director will lead allowing their managers to manage without strings!

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
* Great position to be introduced to biological research while a student.
* Allows for the development of skills and also academic knowledge through lab and department meetings as well as conferences.
* It is very easy to develop mentors and also get a head start in research by participating in authoring research.
cons:
* Experience of the job is highly dependent on the Principal Investigator and the culture of the lab.
* May sometimes require working on weekends or later than the work hours during the week.
* There is a significant learning curve for someone with no prior experience but that goes away with time.

pros:
1. Great Benefits.
2. Up to $8000 school reimbursement.
3. Great salary! Better than other hospitals I've worked at.
4. Excellent department management.
5. Organized hierarchy.
6. Great working environment.
7. Cultural differences are highly respected.
cons: The only con is that there is very little room for advancement. From my experience at Penn is a highly organized facility as such there's not room for advancement as everyone I've encounter likes working here. However, no one is looking to leave. As a medical assistant there are opportunities to move from clinical to administrative positions and back.

review_title: Once you're in take advantage of the opportunities to make a difference!
pros: Once you get your foot in the door, UPHS is a place where you can establish a career and take advantages of numerous opportunities. Being a part of UPenn is an added benefit.
cons: Being a non-profit, salaries tend to be on the lower side of the range. Additionally, depending on your grade level, certain transfers could result in no increase in pay.

pros: Management are mandated to follow up on employee engagement surveys. The surveys are to address areas of improvement to engage employees.
cons: Management not addressing real issues.  They pick what "Item" to work on and steer the meetings accordingly. For us, our top 2 issues were dismissed completely and rather an archaic idea is being presented.  Also, seems to be retaliation to those who appeared to be the persons who may have rated low and spoke out about their concern.

review_title: They set the ideal for a challenging and rewarding career in medicine. I left to move 200 miles away for family reasons.
job_title: Medical Staff HUP in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Daily multidisciplinary rounds keep communication between all departments clear and optimize patient care. Dedicated long term nursing staff are committed to the patient's goals. Colleagues in subspecialties available in the click of a text to assist in a patient's good outcome.
cons: Generous time off, but you really had to arrange your own coverage. Definitely consider living within a bike ride to avoid a grinding commute.

review_title: Great place to learn and be given growth opportunity as new RN
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Big academic hospital comes with its pros and cons itself but a great place to learn and evidence for decision making is valued. Hands down the best nurses I've worked with. intelligent, diligent and fun to work with.
cons: Should support nurses more. Ratios are ok but given the incredibly high acuity and volume - for which the Hospital is in desperate need of its planned expansion - there should be more float nurses/extra support. I probably took an actual lunch 10 times in my 4 years there.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Phila, PA
pros: Decent pay. Great Doctors.
cons: Can't use sick time for when you actually become sick or for doctor appts.

job_title: Clinical Nurse Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I love to learn about science, medical research, medical trends. I work with very bright people from which I can learn. This is an added benefit for me. I am able to ask questions & share impressions.
cons: Pay could always be better, this would help staff to feel valued. System is slow to respond to issues, too much red tape.

review_title: Worst place to work... Target case management (hall Mercer)
pros: Great pay... That's all and benefits
cons: Worst supervisors ever. Don't train properly, can you say OVERWORKED!!!! Most nights you don't leave until sunset. Tons of paper work, no connection with your team cause you work in a darn dangerous environment 75% the day (streets). Unrealistic quotas you have to meet. Your job is never good enough . supervision is a time to let the employee know everything they doing wrong and threaten they job. Work place bullying, these folks don't value anything but if your bringing 16 units in daily. The ABSOLUTE worst job ever I rather work at Mc Donalds. Do not apply you will wind up being 302d yourself.

review_title: Pretty good, tuition reimbursment, pleasant work environment (at one point).
job_title: Medical Records Clerk in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Good location, Opportunities to progress, Training and Tuition Reimbursment... Early one I was able to take advantage of many of the benefits allowed through Penn medicine but managment is key as lately I have experiences many negative changes.
cons: Behind the scenes issues, CCA Senior management, much more restrictions than other entities. It seems as though we are paid less for the same level of work, and also recieve less in benefits.

pros: Excellent leaders teaching the incoming generations about all aspects of business including but not limited to professionalism, confidence, and hard work.
cons: While you learn a lot solely by watching these powerful leaders your tasks are minimal and simple. This may be great for the lazy employee but not so great for the employee eager to work hard.

review_title: Great Company w/ Incredible Benefits & Growth Potential
pros: Excellent company that allows ample flexibility with their employees to explore new roles and challenges. Be assertive in what you want to do, there are a lot of incredible things happening, so if you want to be a part of the action, just ask and promote yourself.
cons: Politics, less than market pay, and no incremental raises- demotivates high performers.

pros: The benefits are very good, and very reasonably priced.  The employment is generally very stable, and layoffs are pretty well unheard of, at least en masse.  Salary is competitive, but on the lower side of the range.  401(k) matching and tuition benefits are very good.  Some of the best management I've seen in a large organization, and a very financially stable organization.
cons: It can be a bureaucratic place, as you might expect with any large organization.  Once you learn the ropes, though, it's not so bad.

pros: Penn values the nurses skill, judgement, and needs.  They promote a comfortable working environment.
cons: Because of it's sheer size, sometimes there was difficulty connecting different service lines.  For example dietary option for patients was limited and often not in the best interest of the patients especially in ordering healthy dietetic options.

pros: Very exciting place with a lot of opportunities.  Very stimulating.  Amazing colleagues who are very bright, motivated and accomplished.  Plenty of opportunities for mentorship for young faculty.
cons: It is not clear to me at this time what the future is for a non researcher in terms of leadership positions and independence.  Seems like clinicians are at the mercy of RVU goals.  Certainly there are a lot of "bosses" who have a say in what I do.  Not a lot of control over my own schedule.

pros: The charecter and quality of the administration of the school of nursing having dual roles in hospital generated a high quality of care.  The patient care and optimal outcome was really the underlying driving force in the buisness.  What was best for the patient was what was the trump card for everything.
cons: There is only one HUP.

pros: Second best wages in the Philadelphia Area. Good benefits. Top Physicians and Nurses. Fast paced, busy environment. Philadelphia is awesome. Outstanding reputation.
cons: Although the physician and nursing corps. are the best among the best I've ever met, other hospitals in the area actually are more enjoyable places to work, and other hospitals may actually pay better. Gossip, paranoia and subterfuge are rampant realities.

pros:
Dedicated, helpful, friendly, coworkers
Low turnover rate
Rich history
Good benefits (time off and insurance)
Decent pay
For the most part, you can leave your work at work and not have to take it home
Location -- near public transportation and relatively safe
cons:
Increasing focus on productivity/costs (as is happening everywhere in health care these days)
ancillary services (such as social work, physical, occupational and speech therapy) are stretched thin

pros: Good benefits.  Tuition benefit is pre-paid, not reimbursed. That's a big plus.
cons: No merit based raises. Usually, raises are 3% across the board. You can bust your butt and the person next to you can twiddle their thumbs. Doesn't matter, you both get the same raise. No employee advocates.

pros: Great salary, flexible schedule, good benefits. I think overall it's a good place to work. Management seems to care about their nurses' happiness and work/life balance.
cons: You have to pay for parking and at times you feel like just a number. Have been trying to drop to part time for a while and have been told that I need to wait.

pros: Worked in the Infectious Diseases Unit initially as a volunteer and then part-time. I feel I was paid fairly for my work there. Office environment in clean and open, and clinic visits, as well as talks and meetings, take you out of the office from time to time. All staff was very welcoming and overall great - positive and encouraging about their jobs and really invested in the study of HIV/AIDS.
cons: No cons come to mind. I had a really great time working there.

review_title: Best Place I Have Ever Worked
pros: My department is more like a little family than having co-workers.  Everyone gets along, have each others backs, and upper management is very approachable.  You are encouraged to fix systems that could be ran better.  I have no complaints
cons: I do not have any cons yet but I have only been working here for 3 months.

pros: A leader in the healthcare industry. Penn Medicine is continually striving to improve the quality of care delivered to our patients. Overall, nurses provided patient-centered, evidenced-based care. Provides exceptional training, encourages education and advancement,  competitive pay and benefits.
cons: At times, it is a high-stress environment with a  high volume of patients. Expected to be adaptable to processes that are constantly changing and improving.

pros: Liked my co workers. Liked the patient population I cared for. Good pay but worked a lot.
cons: HR not helpful. Management is terrible. If you’re not well liked by management on the floor then stay under the radar. Hard to keep up with social life outside of work. Not flexible with family or personal emergencies. Penn thinks they’re the best when there is much room for improvement. Worked there for two years and saw some horrific things done by other nurses, nothing would be done by management because the nurses were well liked or went to penn. Toxic work environment.

review_title: Management is disconnected from those working at the ground level.
job_title: Clinical Services Associate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great physicians to work for/with, solid benefits, large system allows movement within without leaving altogether
cons: Management is completely disconnected from how policies affect those who actually have to follow them, a huge management team means changes occur at a snail's pace, hard-work and accountability is discouraged in favor of making sure that no one ever gets their feelings hurt

review_title: Welcoming, engaging, and interesting place to work.
pros: It is clear that the focus is on the patients, which gives everybody's job a higher purpose. There is a great sense of camaraderie among the employees, and it's really nice to have our own campus and part of the city.
cons: There is a lot of administrative bureaucracy that sometimes makes it difficult to operate efficiently, and a lot of institutional barriers to change.

review_title: The UPenn Health System combines professionalism, academic opportunities, and a pleasant work culture all in one.
pros: There are flexible work hours with a overall culture of success.  In terms of pay, pay is scaled based on your prior work experience and ability to contribute.  There are also a variety of benefits from health insurance to tuition benefits.
cons:
Difficulty finding parking at times
Stagnant salary scaling upon working

job_title: Nuclear Stress Technician in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Lots of opportunity to work in other roles through the department as a per diem employee, and conscientious management and coworkers
cons: Can be hard to get an interview since the company is very reputable and has many applicants. Get a foot in the door by working per diem then eventually you may have the opportunity to go full time.

review_title: I really enjoyed the personal experience of working on a small research team
pros: The people and the resources were great. It was also nice how diverse the group of people I was surrounded by were. Furthermore, Penn Medicine has numerous events for personal growth and development and to learn about other current projects.
cons: The facilities hindered our ability to conduct work on occasion. I was working in a laboratory that does animal testing and they would stress the animals by moving them.

pros: Best Place to work as an Intern. Fast pace and get to meet senior staff. Get to work on various projects that actually help the department.
cons: Can be boring at times. Work can be slow, especially since the internship takes place during the summer. Crowd can be older at times and no one to relate to besides fellow interns.

pros: Flexible schedule, Project Manager provided constructive criticism that guided the process in a positive way, Regular meetings that were short and to the point,
cons: Overall, my experience was positive with the Project Manager. However, his/her higher ups were presumptuous and made suggestions that made absolutely no sense.

review_title: Great academic opportunities, but frustrated translating that into a better salary.
pros: Always new learning opportunities. Great for type A folks. Driven people, fertile environment. I feel pushed to succeed, and it makes me better at my job.
cons: Funding goes to docs, but few other departments. We have lasers that can cure cancer, but departments have to promise their first born just to get new office chairs & functional equipment.

pros: HUP provides excellent patient care. The doctor's and staff have excellent bedside manner pertaining to inpatient and outpatient health care.
cons: Had a slip and fall on the job. Dr. and nurses in employee health treated me like a criminal. Ignored all of my health conditions. I was prescribed muscle relaxants and sent back to my office. Staff at employee health and my supervisor , stated that I was faking. Even though outpatient's and co-workers witnessed my fall.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The pro for this position was that you can receive up to 8k tuition assistance per year.
cons: Most people in the access center take the job as a “foot in the door” with penn medicine but it is not the reality of the situation. Managers and supervisors at the access center do what they can to keep you there. Theres very few people who are able to move around Penn due to their desire to hold people back.

review_title: Penn Med Home Health and Hospice leadership creates a toxic environment
job_title: Registered Nurse Case Manager in Bala Cynwyd, PA
pros: You can develop close relationships with your patients and communities.
cons:
Scheduling is a mess. 
Training is a mess.
Documentation is a mess.
No accountability.
Productivity measures are unreasonable.
Poor communication all around.
New processes implemented with little training and poor execution.
Micromanagement is the norm; Directors want control over everything and it affects staff. 
Major diversity issues in leadership and unsupportive [though, fully aware] HR dept.

pros: Good environment with people who truly care about patient care. They often can be short-staffed and view students as employers first and second students who need learning opportunities.
cons: No increase in pay when going from CNA to Nurse Extern. View students as employee first and learning and new experiences comes second.

pros: I like that I am able to work with a group of people as a team. I like that there is a collaborative effort made to help patients get better.
cons: 12 hour shifts, day night rotation,

pros: Good experience, especially if you want to go on to graduate school. The UPENN name carries a lot of weight in other schools. I think it helped me alot when I moved on to graduate school, so if you can put up with it for a little bit, I think it pays off in the long run.
cons: Terrible management (could have been particular to my field) was the worst part.

review_title: Good in the beginning. However, as all of medicine recently, more concerned with money and how many patients can be done
pros: Wonderful technology and shear brain power. Very stimulating intellectually. Cutting edge medicine.
cons: Politically brutal. More emphasis on through put than patient empathy. Employee wise it's "If you can't keep up, get out, there are ten people waiting to take your job."

review_title: A Hand Up not a hand out
pros: I am grateful for the educational and work experience I received at The Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania.
cons: I have no cons that are not afforded to all University based teaching hospitals.

job_title: Business Manager in Haddon Township, NJ
pros: Friendly coworkers, great work Life Balance, plenty of PTO (vacation, personal, sick)
cons:
Beauracratic and Political as hell. Its who you know, not what you know. People are known to be in tight knit cliques and tend to not share information.
When you take off that is frown upon at times......

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros: Friendly caring staff.   Coworkers make the position fun and exciting. Clean bright building with a parking garage.
cons: Management has favorites within the department.   When someone is off or calls out the coworker is not replaced and the rest of the department works short staffed.

job_title: Family Nurse Practitioner in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
- Penn Medicine as a system is a wonderful place to work with fair benefits and pay. This review is for Penn Family Care at 3737 Market. I would avoid this clinic if you are a less experienced Nurse Practitioner. If you choose to interview here as a Nurse Practitioner, I would suggest you adopt the policy that you are interviewing them, not the other way around to ensure it is a good fit. They are friendly on the surface, but not very supportive and can be harsh.
- H.R. is great at assisting in your on boarding.
- The support staff is friendly and helpful. 
- This is a large office so it is hard to generalize the doctors, but some of them were very helpful.
- The few NP's that work here are as helpful as they can be, but they are spread thin.
cons:
- Leadership lacks vision and are unable to lay out clear expectations. 
- Leadership is very poor at communication both with staff and amongst each other. 
- The organizational structure does not clearly delineate with whom to address grievances, nor does it adequately define leadership roles. 
- There is no formal orientation process. It is a 'hit the ground running' type of environment. 
- There is poor inter-disciplinary communication.
- This is not a friendly environment for newer Nurse Practitioners. 
- You would be mistaken to think that, because this is a place with residents, that will translate into better education and mentorship for NP's. It is the opposite.
- The job expectations and description expressed to me in my interviews were not true, and were contradicted upon starting my employment.

review_title: Good Benes But Difficult to Get Promoted
